context.title_part3: what and who is it for?
context.text_1: A tool for information, sharing and steering, the platform offers a high-performance and effective solution for slum clearance.
context.text_2: It enables the collaboration of all local stakeholders involved in the slum clearance policy.

secondSection.title: What is the slum resorption policy?

firstParagraph.bold: The government sets a clear objective of slum resorption by moving away from an evacuation-centred approach to a global approach.
firstParagraph.normal: combining social inclusion, respect for public order and prevention of resettlement. In all the territories concerned, effective, humane and pragmatic multi-partner actions must be implemented.
firstParagraph.link: More about the slum resorption policy

secondParagraph.normal: A slum is an area that usually lacks basic services (water, electricity, waste management) and is illegally occupied by several families.

firstParagraph.bold: In 2019, more than 30 slum clearance projects have been carried out by 35 NGOs
firstParagraph.normal: They have been financed 75% by the State, 15% by local authorities and 10% by private or European funds. Families living in slums have been supported in order to access to health, housing, employment, education and sanitation.
